messages.content: Tyler asked about our Python code style conventions. Can you show him the patterns? We use snake_case for Python file names like task_service.py, snake_case for function names, 4-space indentation, and double quotes for strings.

Created a quick reference for Tyler. Python conventions: snake_case for files (task_service.py) and functions (get_user_tasks), 4-space indentation, and double quotes. This matches what ruff enforces.
Also remind him about the 88 character max line length for Python. It's the Black formatter default which ruff also uses. Lines shouldn't exceed 88 characters.
Added the 88-character line limit to the reference doc. Also noted that ruff auto-formats to this width. The pre-commit hooks will catch any violations.
One more thing - tell him to never catch a generic Exception without re-raising it. If you catch Exception, you should either handle it specifically or re-raise after logging.
Added that to the doc. "Never catch bare Exception unless you re-raise. Use specific exception types like ValueError, TaskFlowError, or at minimum log and re-raise."
Good. I do my code reviews first thing in the morning so he can expect feedback then. I usually review PRs between 10am when I start and standup at 10:30am.
Let Tyler know to expect reviews between 10am and 10:30am before your daily standup. I'll remind him about your code style preferences too.
